III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member asked a youth to shower with her and then the
staff member proceeded to take pictures of another youth in the
shower. Both youth have developmental disabilities and function
at different levels.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Therapist was interviewed face to face at the
Children’s Advocacy Center on 2/14/23. Complainant stated
Youth A was complaining about her dislike of Staff 1, which was a
common occurrence. Youth A made a variety of comments
including stating her intent to “jump” Staff 1. When Youth A was
encouraged to find more effective ways to express her needs, she
2

decided to fill out a client’s rights form. On the form, she wrote the
allegations about Staff 1 taking pictures of Youth B in the shower
and offering Youth A money to shower. Prior to writing this note,
Youth A had never expressed any concerns about Staff 1 acting
sexually inappropriate with her or Youth B. Complainant reported
he has not personally witnessed any inappropriate behaviors or
concerns between Staff 1 and Youth A or Youth B. Complainant
reported Youth B has a hygiene intervention plan developed by
the Behavior Intervention Team, but Youth A does not.
Observed CAC Interview for Youth A conducted by CAC
Interviewer on 2/14/23. Youth A reported Staff 1 is a creep
because she asks people to take showers. Youth A stated Staff 1
asked her to take a shower with her once. Youth A stated when
she was washing her body in the shower, she saw Staff 1
reaching her arm in the bathroom taking pictures of Youth A with
her phone. Youth A reported she knew Staff 1 was taking pictures
because she was pressing on the screen of her phone. Youth A
reported the door to the bathroom was open because she wanted
to listen to music. She reported she did not have a Bluetooth
speaker or MP3 player, so Staff 1 was playing music for Youth A
on her phone. Youth A reported Staff 1 took pictures of Youth B
too. Youth A did not see it happen but heard Staff 1 giggling and
Staff 1 always giggles when she is doing something wrong. Youth
A stated one time she was vacuuming the hallway by where the
bathroom was and saw Staff 1 touching Youth B’s private parts in
the bathroom. Youth A specified Staff 1 was touching Youth B’s
breasts with her hands and Youth B did not have clothes on, but
Staff 1 did. Youth A stated she does not know if anything else
happened because she “didn’t want any part of what was
happening” and walked away. Youth A reported shortly after she
began staying at the facility, she went with two other youth, Staff 1
and Staff 2 to Walmart for an outing. Youth A reported when they
were leaving Walmart, she was sitting in the back seat with one
youth and Staff 1 and Staff 1 was masturbating in the back seat.
When asked to demonstrate, Youth A used her hands to scratch
the inside of her thighs. Youth A reported one time Staff 1 showed
Youth A a picture of Staff 1’s breasts she had on her phone. Youth
A reported Staff 1 made her feel uncomfortable and was always
weird.
Observed CAC Interview for Youth B conducted by a CAC
Interviewer on 2/14/23. Youth B was unable to be interviewed
due to her lack of verbal skills and limited cognitive functioning.
3

Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/15/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law
Enforcement. Supervisor reported each youth requires a different
level of intervention on the unit. He stated Youth B requires a little
more assistance in the shower, but the level of assistance she
needs has decreased as she’s been in the program. He stated
she is now to the point where staff only have to apply shampoo to
her hair, and put soap in a washcloth, but she can wash all of the
soap out of her hair and off her body. Supervisor reported at times
staff will use their phones to play music for youth when they
shower if the youth does not have a Bluetooth speaker or MP3
player. Staff are encouraged to provide the youth with as much
dignity and respect as possible when showering and staff are
instructed to do as little as possible to assist. Supervisor reported
Staff 1 was very excited to work with the youth and came on a
little too strong while trying to build relationships with them.
Supervisor reported the youth in the program can be standoffish
due to the trauma they’ve endured, and Staff 1 struggled with that,
so she tended to push harder. She was coached to instead do
“parallel play” with the youth to avoid coming on to strong in her
interactions. Supervisor reported none of the youth have
specifically complained about Staff 1 until this incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/28/23. Staff 1 reported
she has never played music for Youth A on her phone because
Youth A has always had her own MP3 player. Staff 1 reported one
time when Youth A was about to take a shower, Youth A asked
another staff member to get her a charger for her MP3 player. The
staff member then asked Staff 1 to grab the charger because the
other staff began helping another resident. Staff 1 reported she
opened the bathroom door, yelled Youth A’s name, and handed
her the charger. She reported she stuck her hand into the
bathroom, but never looked inside the bathroom or walked into the
bathroom. Staff 1 reported Youth B needs prompting for her
showers because she really enjoys showers and would stay under
the water for hours if she could. Staff 1 reported the only tasks she
has had to help Youth A with are putting shampoo in her hands
and putting body wash on the loofah. Staff 1 reported Youth B can
complete everything else independently. Staff 1 reported there
have been a few times when she has helped Youth B dry her back
off with the towel because she has difficulty doing so and then has
trouble putting her clothes on when her back is wet, but that has
only happened a few times. Staff 1 reported she was not
masturbating in the back of the car when leaving the outing from
Walmart. She reported it was an extremely cold night and she
remembered she put her hands in between her thighs to help
4

warm her hands from the frigid temperatures, but nothing else.
Staff 1 reported she has never forced the youth to pick her to help
them with showers. She reported the only things she said at staff
meeting was she felt allowing the youth to pick the staff member
to help them every time creates favoritism amongst staff and can
also be disruptive to staff routines during shifts if the staff member
the youth picks is involved in another responsibility at the time.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement.
Staff 2 reported she drove to and from the outing to Walmart and
none of the youth appeared upset or stated they were
uncomfortable with any actions by anyone during the trip. Staff 2
reported she felt sometimes Staff 1 would push herself onto the
youth around shower time by saying “how about I help you with
your shower tonight” or “I’m going to help you with your shower
tonight” rather than asking for the youth’s preference. Staff 2
confirmed Youth A has had an MP3 player since coming to the
facility and plays music on that when she showers. Staff 2
reported one time, soon after Youth A arrived at the facility, Staff 1
was sitting in a chair across from the door of the bathroom where
Youth A was showering. Staff 2 reported she thought it was odd
Staff 1 was sitting outside the door because Youth A did not need
any assistance with showering. Staff 2 reported she wasn’t sure
why it occurred, but never asked. Staff 2 reported she never saw
Staff 1 do anything inappropriate with or towards Youth A or Youth
B.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement.
Staff 3 assisted Youth A with writing the client’s rights form
complaining about Staff 1 per Youth A’s request. Staff 3 reported
she has never worked with Staff 1. Staff 3 reported a previous
youth told her she was uncomfortable with Staff 1, but never
provided any specific information or details as to why she felt that
way.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/15/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker and Law Enforcement.
Staff 4 reported Youth A previously complained about Staff 1
being actively meaner towards her than the other youth. Youth A
reported Staff 1 was holding more of a boundary with her and
following through on set expectations, which Youth A did not like.
Staff 4 is a behavior analyst at the facility and frequently
completes behavior analysis observations on staff interactions
with youth. Staff 4 reported Staff 1 attempted to build rapport with
5

Youth A, but Youth A had no interest in developing a relationship
with her and specifically said she did not want Staff 1 to befriend
her. Staff 4 reported when Youth A first arrived at the facility, there
was a general self-harm plan in place, which stated staff needed
to keep an eye on Youth A in all environments. Although sitting
outside the bathroom wasn’t specifically written in the safety plan,
a staff member sitting outside of the bathroom to keep an eye on
Youth A would have been a reasonable plan or expectation for
that environment. Staff 4 reported she does not have any
concerns with Staff 1’s interactions with youth and has never
received any complaints about Staff 1 from any of the youth. Staff
4 never witnessed any interactions between Staff 1 and any of the
youth that would be considered inappropriate.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Significant Incident report dated 2/1/23 authored by
Complainant/Therapist. Therapist noted Youth A was
expressing dislike of Staff 1, which was a common
occurrence. Youth A stated she intended to “jump Staff 1”.
Youth A chose to file an internal client concern form in
which she reported the allegations of this investigation.
• Client Concern or Complain form dated 2/1/23 authored by
Youth A. Youth A stated she feels uncomfortable when
Staff 1 is working because Staff 1 was taking pictures of
Youth B when Youth B was in the shower. Youth A also
alleged Staff 1 was begging to help Youth A shower and
would give Youth A money to do so. Youth A documented
the incident happened a week prior and she would like Staff
1 moved or fired.
• Youth A Behavior Intervention Plan dated 1/12/23
documents Youth A has endured both physical and sexual
abuse in her past. The intervention plan outlines Youth A’s
risk of self-injury and details options for interactions for
Youth A at her baseline and escalated levels.
• Children’s Advocacy Center of Kent County Forensic
Interview Summary for Youth A dated 2/14/23, which was
consistent with interview summary.
• Children’s Advocacy Center of Kent County Forensic
Interview Summary for Youth B dated 2/14/23, which notes
the interview could not be conducted as Youth B was
unable to participate in the forensic interview process.
6

• Youth B’s Showering Program states staff should ask
Youth B who she would like to help her with her shower.
Staff should be positioned at a distance to provide prompts
when needed. The program outlines the hierarchy of
prompts that should be given which ranges from Verbal
Instruction/Reminder to Full Physical Guidance (always
using the least intrusive prompt necessary).
• Supervision logs ranging in dates from 10/21/22-1/31/23 (7
in total) between Supervisor and Staff 1. Trends of Staff 1’s
individual goals and professional development surround
building rapport with the youth without pushing social
interactions on them, keeping firm expectations without
being harsh/negative tone of voice, and keeping physical
boundaries with youth (let them come to her and interact
rather than her coming to them).
• Shift Fill-In Logs for Shifts Staff 1 worked. Log dated
1/21/23 notes Youth A and another youth went on an outing
to the store with staff. Log also notes Youth A was in a
good space all shift and had no issues to report. Log dated
2/1/23 notes Youth A was heard and observed to be
continuously telling other staff and peers she wrote a
client’s rights form on a staff member.
• Staff 1’s training record notes she had training on
Maintaining Professional Boundaries on 10/20/22 and
another training called Professional Boundaries on 1/16/23.
Staff 1 does not have any write-ups or disciplinary action in
her employee file. She was suspended from work pending
the findings of this investigation.
• Wedgwood Christian Services Professional Staff
Relationships Policy (rev. 8/23/22) outlines appropriate
boundaries between staff and youth in the program.
• Wedgwood Christian Services Physical Contact and
Sexuality Policy (rev. 8/23/22) outlines appropriate
interactions and physical boundaries between staff and
youth; specifically considering the youth’s trauma history.
Analysis Documentation reviewed and interviews conducted suggest Staff
1 was overzealous in her interactions with youth, but there were
no concerns these interactions were sexually inappropriate in
nature. Specific observations from the Supervisor and Staff 4 were
Staff 1 was working on building rapport with the youth and
7

sometimes came on too strong. Although Youth A says Staff 1
acted inappropriately with her and Youth B, it is unknown what
date this may have occurred, or which staff may have been
present. Staff interviewed never witnessed any sexually
inappropriate interactions between Staff 1 and any youth. There is
no evidence to support Staff 1 acted inappropriately with Youth A
or Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
